questions.stem: A 74-year-old patient is brought by family for evaluation of progressive memory loss over 2 years. She repeats questions, misplaces items, and recently got lost driving to a familiar store. Her speech is fluent but increasingly vague, and she shows poor performance on delayed recall tasks even with cueing. Which diagnosis is most consistent with this presentation?

options.text: Major NCD due to vascular disease
Major NCD due to Alzheimer's disease
Major NCD due to frontotemporal degeneration
Major NCD due to Lewy body disease

questions.explanation: This presentation is classic for Alzheimer's disease: insidious onset, gradual progression, early and prominent episodic memory impairment (repeating questions, misplacing items), visuospatial disorientation (getting lost), and fluent but vague language. Critically, the poor performance on delayed recall even with cueing indicates an encoding/storage deficit (cortical dementia pattern), rather than a retrieval deficit (subcortical pattern where cues help). This encoding failure is characteristic of hippocampal pathology in AD.

questions.stem: A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with cognitive decline that his wife describes as 'getting worse in steps rather than gradually.' After each episode of worsening, there is a partial recovery followed by a new decline. Neurological examination reveals gait abnormality and left-sided hyperreflexia. This pattern is most consistent with:

options.text: Major NCD due to Alzheimer's disease
Major NCD due to vascular disease
Major NCD due to Lewy body disease
Major NCD due to Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease

questions.explanation: The stepwise deterioration pattern (worsening in discrete steps rather than gradual decline) is the hallmark of vascular NCD (multi-infarct type). Each step corresponds to a new vascular event (stroke or TIA). The vascular risk factors (hypertension, diabetes), focal neurological signs (gait abnormality, lateralized hyperreflexia), and temporal relationship between episodes and decline all support a vascular etiology. Alzheimer's has a gradual, continuous decline; Lewy body disease has fluctuating cognition but not stepwise; CJD is rapidly progressive over weeks to months.

questions.stem: A 68-year-old patient with dementia and visual hallucinations of children playing in her room is prescribed haloperidol for behavioral management. Within 48 hours, she develops severe rigidity, fever, altered consciousness, and autonomic instability. What is the most likely explanation for this acute deterioration?

options.text: Anticholinergic delirium from haloperidol
Severe neuroleptic sensitivity in dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB)
Expected progression of Alzheimer's disease
Serotonin syndrome from drug interaction

questions.explanation: This is a critically important clinical scenario. Patients with dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) have severe neuroleptic sensitivity -- conventional antipsychotics like haloperidol can trigger life-threatening neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) or severe parkinsonism and worsening. The visual hallucinations (well-formed, detailed images of people/children) are a core feature of DLB. This is one of the most high-yield EPPP facts: antipsychotics should be used with extreme caution (or avoided) in DLB, and if needed, only atypical antipsychotics at very low doses should be considered.

questions.stem: A 58-year-old man presents with progressive personality change over the past year. His wife reports he has become disinhibited, making inappropriate sexual comments in public, and has developed compulsive eating behaviors with a strong preference for sweets. He shows loss of empathy and apathy. Memory testing reveals relatively preserved episodic memory. This presentation is most consistent with:

options.text: Major NCD due to Alzheimer's disease
Behavioral variant frontotemporal NCD (bvFTD)
Major NCD due to Lewy body disease
Delirium with behavioral disinhibition

questions.explanation: Behavioral variant FTD (bvFTD) is characterized by early, prominent personality and behavioral changes: disinhibition, apathy, loss of empathy, compulsive/ritualistic behaviors, and dietary changes including hyperorality and sweet food preference. Critically, memory and visuospatial function are relatively preserved early in the disease course, distinguishing bvFTD from Alzheimer's disease (where memory is the earliest impairment). The younger onset (often 45-65) is also more consistent with FTD than AD.

questions.stem: An elderly hospitalized patient who was cognitively normal before admission develops acute confusion, fluctuating attention, visual hallucinations, and agitation over 24 hours following hip surgery. The nursing staff reports the symptoms are worse at night. This presentation is most consistent with:

options.text: Major NCD due to Alzheimer's disease with acute onset
Major NCD due to Lewy body disease
Delirium
Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.explanation: This is classic delirium: acute onset (hours to days), fluctuating course, impaired attention (hallmark feature), visual hallucinations, altered consciousness, and worsening at night (sundowning). The temporal relationship to a medical event (surgery) and the previously normal cognitive baseline are key distinguishing features. Delirium is a medical emergency that is often reversible when the underlying cause is treated. Alzheimer's has insidious onset over months to years; DLB has chronic fluctuations, not acute post-surgical onset; depression would not typically produce this acute pattern.

questions.stem: Select ALL core clinical features of dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB):

options.text: Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness
Recurrent, well-formed visual hallucinations (e.g., seeing people or animals)
REM sleep behavior disorder (acting out dreams)
Early, prominent personality change with disinhibition and loss of empathy
Spontaneous parkinsonism (rigidity, bradykinesia)

questions.explanation: The four core clinical features of DLB are: (1) fluctuating cognition with variations in attention/alertness, (2) recurrent, well-formed visual hallucinations, (3) REM sleep behavior disorder, and (4) spontaneous parkinsonism. Early personality change with disinhibition and loss of empathy is characteristic of behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD), not DLB. DLB is also notable for severe neuroleptic sensitivity, which is a supportive diagnostic feature.

questions.stem: Select ALL features that distinguish delirium from dementia (major NCD):

options.text: Delirium has acute onset (hours to days) versus insidious onset in dementia
Impaired attention is the hallmark of delirium, while attention is relatively preserved in dementia until late stages
Delirium features altered/clouded consciousness, while consciousness is clear in dementia until late stages
Delirium is always irreversible, while dementia is usually reversible
Delirium is often worse at night (sundowning pattern), with a fluctuating course

questions.explanation: Delirium is distinguished from dementia by: acute onset (hours to days vs. months to years), impaired attention as the hallmark feature, altered/clouded consciousness, fluctuating course worse at night, and reversibility when the underlying cause is treated. Option D has the relationship reversed: delirium is usually REVERSIBLE while dementia is usually IRREVERSIBLE. Importantly, pre-existing dementia is itself a major risk factor for developing delirium.

questions.stem: Select ALL accurate statements about the neuropathology and genetics of Alzheimer's disease:

options.text: Hallmark pathology includes extracellular amyloid plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles (tau)
Pathology typically begins in the entorhinal cortex and hippocampus, explaining early memory symptoms
The APOE-e4 allele is a deterministic gene -- all carriers will develop Alzheimer's disease
Down syndrome (trisomy 21) is associated with markedly elevated AD risk due to the APP gene on chromosome 21
The cholinergic hypothesis proposes that acetylcholine deficiency from degeneration of nucleus basalis of Meynert neurons contributes to cognitive decline

questions.explanation: AD is characterized by amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, beginning in the entorhinal cortex/hippocampus. APOE-e4 is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset AD (one copy = 3-4x risk; two copies = 12-15x risk), but it is a RISK FACTOR, not deterministic -- not all carriers develop AD and many AD patients lack the allele. Down syndrome (trisomy 21) carries elevated AD risk because the APP gene is on chromosome 21. The cholinergic hypothesis (degeneration of nucleus basalis of Meynert) is the basis for cholinesterase inhibitor treatment.

questions.stem: Select ALL conditions that represent potentially REVERSIBLE causes of neurocognitive impairment:

options.text: Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH)
Wernicke encephalopathy (acute thiamine deficiency)
Delirium from anticholinergic medication toxicity
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (prion disease)
Hypothyroidism-induced cognitive impairment

questions.explanation: NPH is one of the few reversible dementias, treatable with VP shunt placement. Wernicke encephalopathy (confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia) is a medical emergency treatable with IV thiamine -- if untreated, it can progress to irreversible Korsakoff syndrome. Delirium from anticholinergic toxicity resolves when the offending medication is removed. Hypothyroidism-induced cognitive symptoms resolve with thyroid hormone replacement. CJD (prion disease) is rapidly progressive and fatal, with no effective treatment.

questions.stem: Select ALL features that distinguish cortical dementia (e.g., Alzheimer's) from subcortical dementia (e.g., Parkinson's disease dementia):

options.text: Cortical dementia features the '4 A's': amnesia, aphasia, agnosia, and apraxia
Subcortical dementia features psychomotor slowing, executive dysfunction, and personality changes
Cortical dementia shows encoding/storage deficits (poor recall even with cues)
Subcortical dementia shows retrieval deficits (poor free recall but improved with cues)
Subcortical dementia typically produces prominent aphasia and agnosia early in the disease

questions.explanation: Cortical dementias (AD) feature the '4 A's' (amnesia, aphasia, agnosia, apraxia) with encoding/storage memory deficits (poor recall that does NOT improve with cueing). Subcortical dementias (Parkinson's, Huntington's) feature psychomotor slowing, executive dysfunction, and personality changes with retrieval-based memory deficits (poor free recall that DOES improve with cueing). Language (aphasia) and recognition (agnosia) are relatively preserved in subcortical dementias -- these are cortical features. This cortical vs. subcortical distinction is heavily tested on the EPPP.

questions.stem: Match each neurocognitive disorder with its most distinguishing clinical feature:

rows.text: NCD due to Lewy body disease

columns.text: Stepwise deterioration with focal neurological signs and cerebrovascular risk factors
Fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, REM sleep disorder, and severe neuroleptic sensitivity
Insidious progressive amnesia with aphasia, agnosia, and apraxia (the '4 A's')
Early personality/behavioral changes with disinhibition, apathy, and relatively preserved memory

questions.explanation: Alzheimer's is characterized by the '4 A's' (amnesia, aphasia, agnosia, apraxia) with insidious onset and gradual progression. DLB features fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, REM sleep behavior disorder, parkinsonism, and critically, severe neuroleptic sensitivity. Behavioral variant FTD shows early personality/behavioral changes (disinhibition, apathy, loss of empathy) with relatively preserved memory. Vascular NCD shows stepwise decline corresponding to cerebrovascular events, with focal neurological signs.

questions.stem: Match each rapidly progressive or distinctive NCD with its characteristic clinical triad or feature set:

columns.text: Severe anterograde amnesia, confabulation, apathy; mammillary body and thalamic damage
Gait disturbance (magnetic gait), urinary incontinence, dementia; ventriculomegaly on imaging
Rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, periodic sharp-wave EEG; fatal within ~1 year
Acute confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia; medical emergency requiring IV thiamine

questions.explanation: CJD (prion disease) presents with rapidly progressive dementia (weeks to months), myoclonus, and periodic sharp-wave complexes on EEG, and is fatal within approximately one year. NPH ('wet, wobbly, wacky') features gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and dementia, with ventriculomegaly on imaging; it is one of the few reversible dementias. Wernicke encephalopathy (acute thiamine deficiency) is a medical emergency presenting with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, requiring immediate IV thiamine. Korsakoff syndrome is the chronic sequela of untreated Wernicke, with severe anterograde amnesia, confabulation, and mammillary body/thalamic damage.

questions.stem: For each neurocognitive disorder, select ALL features that are characteristically associated with it. Some features may apply to more than one disorder.

columns.text: Early memory impairment as the predominant symptom
Early personality/behavioral changes preceding memory loss
Stepwise decline with cerebrovascular risk factors

questions.explanation: Alzheimer's disease is characterized by early, prominent memory impairment as the predominant initial symptom. Behavioral variant FTD features early personality and behavioral changes (disinhibition, apathy, loss of empathy) that precede memory loss. Lewy body dementia includes spontaneous parkinsonism (rigidity, bradykinesia) as one of its core features, along with fluctuating cognition and visual hallucinations. Vascular NCD shows stepwise decline corresponding to cerebrovascular events, with risk factors like hypertension and diabetes.

questions.stem: For each feature, select ALL neurocognitive disorder subtypes where it is a prominent or characteristic finding.

rows.text: Subcortical dementia profile (psychomotor slowing, retrieval deficits)

questions.explanation: Visual hallucinations are a core feature of Lewy body dementia (well-formed, detailed). Executive dysfunction is prominent in frontotemporal NCD (especially bvFTD) and HIV-associated NCD (which follows a subcortical pattern). Subcortical dementia profile (psychomotor slowing, retrieval deficits) characterizes HIV-associated NCD, which preferentially targets basal ganglia and white matter. Younger onset (before age 65) is characteristic of frontotemporal NCD, which typically presents between ages 45-65. Alzheimer's disease typically presents after age 65 (though early-onset forms exist).

questions.stem: In the DSM-5, the distinction between major and mild neurocognitive disorder is primarily based on {{blank1}}. Major NCD involves cognitive decline that {{blank2}}, while mild NCD involves decline that {{blank3}}. The DSM-5 framework recognizes {{blank4}} cognitive domains that can be affected.

options.text: the specific brain region affected
functional independence in everyday activities
the results of neuroimaging studies
the patient's age at onset
does not interfere with daily functioning
interferes with independence in everyday activities
is only detectable on neuropsychological testing
affects only memory and no other domains
interferes with independence but not safety
is too mild to detect on formal testing
does not interfere with independence, though greater effort or accommodations may be needed
only affects procedural memory
four
five
six
eight

questions.explanation: The DSM-5 distinguishes major from mild NCD primarily based on functional independence. Major NCD involves cognitive decline that interferes with independence in everyday activities (e.g., managing finances, driving, medication management). Mild NCD involves modest decline that does not interfere with independence, though greater effort, compensatory strategies, or accommodation may be needed. The DSM-5 recognizes six cognitive domains: complex attention, executive function, learning and memory, language, perceptual-motor, and social cognition.

questions.stem: Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is characterized by the classic triad of {{blank1}}, {{blank2}}, and {{blank3}}. It is remembered by the mnemonic {{blank4}} and is one of the few potentially reversible causes of dementia.

options.text: gait disturbance (magnetic gait)
visual hallucinations
myoclonus
tremor
ophthalmoplegia
urinary incontinence
seizures
hearing loss
aphasia
agnosia
dementia
ataxia
'the 4 A's'
'wet, wobbly, and wacky'
'I WATCH DEATH'
'the 3 D's'

questions.explanation: NPH features the classic triad of gait disturbance (magnetic gait -- wide-based, shuffling, as if feet are stuck to the floor, typically the first and most prominent symptom), urinary incontinence ('wet'), and dementia ('wacky'). The mnemonic is 'wet, wobbly, and wacky.' Neuroimaging shows ventriculomegaly disproportionate to cortical atrophy. Diagnosis is supported by improvement after large-volume lumbar puncture, and treatment is VP shunt placement.

questions.stem: A 72-year-old woman presents with a 3-year history of progressive cognitive decline. Her daughter reports she frequently repeats the same questions within minutes, has difficulty finding words (using 'thing' and 'it' instead of specific nouns), recently got lost in her own neighborhood, and can no longer manage her finances independently. On examination, she cannot copy a three-dimensional cube and has difficulty demonstrating how to use a toothbrush on command.

options.text: Amyloid plaques (beta-amyloid) and neurofibrillary tangles (hyperphosphorylated tau)
Cholinergic neuron degeneration in the nucleus basalis of Meynert
Alpha-synuclein Lewy body inclusions throughout the cortex
Misfolded prion proteins causing rapid neuronal death
Major NCD due to Alzheimer's disease
Major NCD due to frontotemporal degeneration
Major NCD due to Lewy body disease
The '4 A's': amnesia, aphasia, agnosia, and apraxia (cortical dementia pattern)
Pathology begins in entorhinal cortex/hippocampus, spreading to temporal, parietal, then frontal cortex
Personality change and disinhibition are the earliest and most prominent symptoms
Fluctuating cognition with vivid visual hallucinations and parkinsonism

questions.explanation: This presentation demonstrates the classic Alzheimer's disease pattern: progressive amnesia (repeating questions), aphasia (word-finding difficulty), agnosia (getting lost reflecting visuospatial impairment), and apraxia (cannot demonstrate toothbrush use). The neuropathology involves amyloid plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, and cholinergic neuron loss in the nucleus basalis of Meynert. The disease begins in the entorhinal cortex and hippocampus, explaining why memory is the earliest deficit. Alpha-synuclein inclusions characterize Lewy body disease, not AD.

questions.stem: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his family. He was well yesterday but today is confused, unable to focus on conversation, appears to see things that are not there, and alternates between agitation and lethargy. He has a history of mild cognitive impairment. His temperature is 101.4F and he appears dehydrated.

options.text: Acute infection (fever suggests underlying infectious process)
Dehydration and metabolic derangement
Progressive beta-amyloid plaque accumulation reaching a critical threshold
Repeated subclinical strokes causing stepwise vascular damage
Delirium superimposed on mild cognitive impairment
Acute onset of major NCD due to Alzheimer's disease
Major NCD due to Lewy body disease
Acute onset (hours to days), fluctuating course, impaired attention as hallmark feature
Usually reversible when underlying cause (infection, dehydration) is treated
Insidious onset over months with gradually progressive course
Clear consciousness with preserved attention throughout the episode

questions.explanation: This is delirium superimposed on pre-existing mild cognitive impairment. Key indicators: acute onset (well yesterday, confused today), fluctuating consciousness (agitation alternating with lethargy), impaired attention, visual hallucinations, and identifiable precipitants (fever suggesting infection, dehydration). Pre-existing cognitive impairment is itself a major risk factor for delirium. Delirium is characterized by acute onset, fluctuating course, impaired attention, and altered consciousness, and is usually reversible when the underlying cause is treated. AD has insidious onset over months to years, not hours.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL clinically accurate statements about neurocognitive disorders.
questions.passage: A clinical neuropsychologist is preparing a grand rounds presentation on NCDs. [Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of major NCD, accounting for 60-80% of dementia cases, characterized by amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles]. [The APOE-e4 allele is a deterministic gene that guarantees Alzheimer's disease development in all carriers by age 75]. [Vascular NCD classically shows a stepwise deterioration pattern, with each step corresponding to a new cerebrovascular event]. [In dementia with Lewy bodies, conventional antipsychotics should be used as first-line treatment for visual hallucinations to ensure rapid symptom control]. [The distinction between major and mild NCD is primarily based on whether cognitive decline interferes with functional independence in everyday activities]. [Frontotemporal NCD typically presents with memory impairment as the earliest and most prominent symptom, similar to Alzheimer's disease].

highlightableSegments.text: Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of major NCD, accounting for 60-80% of dementia cases, characterized by amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles
The APOE-e4 allele is a deterministic gene that guarantees Alzheimer's disease development in all carriers by age 75
Vascular NCD classically shows a stepwise deterioration pattern, with each step corresponding to a new cerebrovascular event
In dementia with Lewy bodies, conventional antipsychotics should be used as first-line treatment for visual hallucinations to ensure rapid symptom control
The distinction between major and mild NCD is primarily based on whether cognitive decline interferes with functional independence in everyday activities
Frontotemporal NCD typically presents with memory impairment as the earliest and most prominent symptom, similar to Alzheimer's disease

questions.explanation: Statements 1, 3, and 5 are correct. Statement 2 is wrong: APOE-e4 is a RISK FACTOR, not a deterministic gene -- not all carriers develop AD and many AD patients lack the allele. Statement 4 is critically wrong: patients with DLB have SEVERE neuroleptic sensitivity and conventional antipsychotics can be life-threatening; they should be avoided or used only with extreme caution. Statement 6 is wrong: FTD typically presents with personality/behavioral changes (not memory impairment) as the earliest symptom, which is a key differentiator from AD.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL clinically accurate statements about specific neurocognitive disorder subtypes and their features.
questions.passage: A psychiatry resident is reviewing rare NCDs for boards. [Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a prion disease causing rapidly progressive dementia (weeks to months), myoclonus, and periodic sharp-wave complexes on EEG, with death typically within one year]. [Normal pressure hydrocephalus is characterized by the triad of gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and dementia, and is potentially reversible with VP shunt placement]. [HIV-associated NCD follows a cortical dementia pattern with prominent aphasia, agnosia, and apraxia as the earliest features]. [Korsakoff syndrome results from chronic thiamine deficiency and is characterized by severe anterograde amnesia and confabulation, with mammillary body damage]. [Wernicke encephalopathy is a chronic, slowly progressive condition that does not require urgent medical intervention]. [The behavioral variant of FTD is characterized by younger onset (often 45-65), disinhibition, apathy, and loss of empathy, with relatively preserved memory early on].

highlightableSegments.text: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a prion disease causing rapidly progressive dementia (weeks to months), myoclonus, and periodic sharp-wave complexes on EEG, with death typically within one year
Normal pressure hydrocephalus is characterized by the triad of gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and dementia, and is potentially reversible with VP shunt placement
HIV-associated NCD follows a cortical dementia pattern with prominent aphasia, agnosia, and apraxia as the earliest features
Korsakoff syndrome results from chronic thiamine deficiency and is characterized by severe anterograde amnesia and confabulation, with mammillary body damage
Wernicke encephalopathy is a chronic, slowly progressive condition that does not require urgent medical intervention
The behavioral variant of FTD is characterized by younger onset (often 45-65), disinhibition, apathy, and loss of empathy, with relatively preserved memory early on

questions.explanation: Statements 1, 2, 4, and 6 are correct. Statement 3 is wrong: HIV-associated NCD follows a SUBCORTICAL dementia pattern (psychomotor slowing, executive dysfunction, retrieval-based memory deficits), NOT a cortical pattern. HIV preferentially targets subcortical structures (basal ganglia, white matter). Statement 5 is wrong: Wernicke encephalopathy is an ACUTE medical emergency (confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia) requiring IMMEDIATE IV thiamine. If untreated, it can progress to irreversible Korsakoff syndrome.

questions.stem: Arrange the clinical stages of Alzheimer's disease in the correct temporal progression from earliest to latest:

items.text: Episodic memory impairment: repeating questions, misplacing items, forgetting recent events; procedural and remote memory preserved
Word-finding difficulty and mild executive dysfunction; patients may show anosognosia (lack of awareness of deficits)
Visuospatial disorientation (getting lost), language deterioration, apraxia, behavioral symptoms (agitation, sundowning)
May not recognize family members; delusions of theft and paranoia; wandering behavior
Severe cognitive decline across all domains; loss of ability to speak coherently
Loss of ability to walk and swallow; incontinence; bedbound state; death (average 8-10 years from diagnosis)

questions.explanation: Alzheimer's disease follows a characteristic progression: (1) Early episodic memory impairment with preserved procedural and remote memory; (2) Word-finding difficulty and executive dysfunction emerge; (3) Middle-stage features including visuospatial problems, language deterioration, apraxia, and behavioral symptoms; (4) Failure to recognize familiar people, paranoid delusions, wandering; (5) Severe decline across all cognitive domains with loss of coherent speech; (6) Terminal stage with loss of motor function, swallowing, and independence. Average duration from diagnosis to death is 8-10 years.

questions.stem: Arrange the following steps in the correct sequence for clinical evaluation of a patient presenting with suspected neurocognitive disorder:

items.text: Detailed history from patient AND informant (family member) about onset, course, and functional impact
Rule out delirium: assess attention, consciousness, onset acuity, and check for medical/toxic causes
Medical workup: CBC, metabolic panel, thyroid function (TSH/T4), B12, RPR/VDRL, urinalysis
Structural neuroimaging (MRI preferred) to evaluate for atrophy patterns, vascular disease, masses, or hydrocephalus
Neuropsychological assessment to characterize the cognitive profile and severity across domains
Integrate findings to determine NCD etiology (AD, vascular, DLB, FTD, etc.) and formulate treatment plan

questions.explanation: Evaluating suspected NCD follows a systematic approach: (1) Comprehensive history from both patient and informant to establish onset, course, and functional impact; (2) Rule out delirium first, as it is a medical emergency and can mimic dementia; (3) Medical workup to identify treatable causes (hypothyroidism, B12 deficiency, syphilis, metabolic derangement); (4) Neuroimaging to assess structural correlates and rule out masses, hydrocephalus, or vascular disease; (5) Neuropsychological testing to characterize the cognitive profile; (6) Integrate all findings to determine the most likely etiology and plan treatment.

questions.stem: A geriatric neuropsychologist tracks cognitive performance over 5 years in three groups: patients with Alzheimer's disease, patients with vascular NCD, and healthy age-matched controls. The outcome measure is a composite cognitive score (higher = better).
questions.question: Which pattern best characterizes the cognitive decline trajectories in these two dementia groups?

options.text: Both dementia groups decline at identical rates, making them clinically indistinguishable
Alzheimer's disease shows a continuous, gradual decline, while vascular NCD shows a more variable, stepwise pattern with periods of relative stability between declines
Vascular NCD shows faster overall decline than Alzheimer's disease at every time point
Both groups improve with treatment, reaching healthy control levels by Year 5

questions.explanation: The data show that Alzheimer's disease follows a continuous, relatively smooth downward trajectory (consistent with the gradual, progressive nature of amyloid and tau pathology). Vascular NCD shows a more variable decline pattern with uneven drops (Years 2-3 drop more steeply followed by relative stability, then another drop), reflecting the stepwise nature of vascular events. In this dataset, both groups start at the same level but AD shows slightly faster overall decline by Year 5. The key distinguishing feature is the pattern of decline: smooth/gradual (AD) versus variable/stepwise (vascular).

questions.stem: A clinical trial follows patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) over 4 years, tracking conversion rates to major NCD. Participants are stratified by APOE-e4 allele status: non-carriers, heterozygous carriers (one copy), and homozygous carriers (two copies).
questions.question: What conclusion about APOE-e4 and Alzheimer's disease risk is best supported by these data?

options.text: APOE-e4 is a deterministic gene -- 100% of homozygous carriers will convert to major NCD
APOE-e4 shows a dose-response relationship: more copies confer greater risk and faster conversion, but it is a risk factor, not deterministic -- many carriers do not convert
APOE-e4 status has no meaningful impact on conversion rates from MCI to major NCD
Only homozygous carriers are at elevated risk; heterozygous carriers have the same risk as non-carriers

questions.explanation: The data demonstrate a clear dose-response relationship: homozygous carriers (two copies) have the highest and fastest conversion rate (72% by Year 4), heterozygous carriers (one copy) have an intermediate rate (42%), and non-carriers have the lowest rate (18%). However, APOE-e4 is NOT deterministic: even among homozygous carriers, 28% have NOT converted by Year 4, and many non-carriers DO convert. This illustrates that APOE-e4 is a risk factor that increases probability but does not guarantee development of AD -- a critical EPPP distinction.

questions.stem: Categorize each clinical feature as characteristic of cortical or subcortical dementia:

items.text: Aphasia, agnosia, and apraxia (the higher cortical dysfunctions)
Psychomotor slowing and bradyphrenia (slowed thinking)
Encoding/storage memory deficit (poor recall even with cues)
Retrieval memory deficit (poor free recall but improved with cueing)
Movement abnormalities (tremor, rigidity, chorea)
Progressive cognitive decline requiring clinical monitoring

questions.explanation: Cortical dementias (Alzheimer's) feature higher cortical dysfunctions: aphasia, agnosia, apraxia, and encoding/storage memory deficits (memories are not properly formed, so cueing does not help recall). Subcortical dementias (Parkinson's, Huntington's, HIV) feature psychomotor slowing, retrieval-based memory deficits (memories are stored but difficult to access, so cueing improves performance), and associated movement disorders. Progressive cognitive decline requiring monitoring is common to both types. This cortical vs. subcortical distinction is among the most heavily tested concepts on the EPPP.

questions.stem: Categorize each feature as most characteristic of delirium or dementia:

items.text: Acute onset over hours to days
Insidious onset over months to years
Impaired attention as the hallmark cognitive deficit
Usually reversible when the underlying cause is identified and treated
Usually irreversible with progressive deterioration over time
Visual hallucinations and perceptual disturbances

questions.explanation: Delirium is characterized by acute onset, impaired attention as the hallmark feature, altered consciousness, and reversibility when the underlying cause is treated. Dementia has insidious onset over months to years and is usually irreversible and progressive. Visual hallucinations can occur in both: they are common in delirium and also occur in specific dementia subtypes (particularly DLB, where well-formed visual hallucinations are a core feature). This delirium vs. dementia distinction is one of the most frequently tested differential diagnoses on the EPPP.
